abstract.text: AFTER@LHC is an ambitious fixed-target project in order to address open questions in the domain of proton and neutron spins, Quark Gluon Plasma and high-x physics, at the highest energy ever reached in the fixed-target mode.

Indeed, thanks to the highly energetic 7 TeV proton and 2.76 A.TeV lead LHC beams, center-of-mass energies as large as √ s NN = 115 GeV in pp/pA and √ s NN = 72 GeV in AA can be reached, corresponding to an uncharted energy domain between SPS and RHIC.
We report two main ways of performing fixed-target collisions at the LHC, both allowing for the usage of one of the existing LHC experiments.
In these proceedings, after discussing the projected luminosities considered for one year of data taking at the LHC, we will present a selection of projections for light and heavy-flavour production.

body_text.text: Introduction
The AFTER@LHC project [1] is a proposal to conduct a multi-purpose fixed-target experiment at the LHC by using its highly energetic proton and lead beams.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The energy domain which can be probed ranges from √ s NN = 72 GeV in AA collisions up to √ s NN = 115 GeV in pp/pA collisions, i.e. the largest energies achieved in the fixed-target mode.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: This mode offers unique opportunities to access the high Feynman-x F domain with high luminosities thanks to the large density of the target.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The versatility of the target also allows one to perform studies as a function of the nucleus atomic mass.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Finally, depending on the chosen technology, it may be possible to polarise the target.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The physics programme of AFTER@LHC has extensively been discussed in Refs [2][3][4][5] and proposes to address open questions in the domain of high-x, Spin and Quark Gluon Plasma (QGP) physics.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In the high-x programme, the aim is to advance our understanding of the high-x gluon, antiquark and heavy-quark content in the nucleon and in the nucleus: by, for instance, constraining the quark Parton Distribution Functions (PDF) and nuclear PDFs (in the EMC region) with Drell-Yan measurements; by searching for the existence of a possible non-perturbative source of c or b quarks in the proton, which is an important input for high-energy-neutrino and cosmic-ray physics; by looking for W boson production near threshold to constrain the light quark sea PDFs at large-x.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In the Spin physics programme (not discussed here), the goal is to advance our understanding of the dynamics and spin of quarks and gluons inside polarised (and unpolarised) nucleons, in particular the Orbital Angular Momentum of quarks and gluons in the proton.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The final part of the AFTER@LHC physics programme concerns the study of heavy-ion collisions toward large rapidities.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In Pb-A collisions, at √ s NN = 72 GeV, AFTER@LHC is probing the region of high temperature (∼ 1.5 T c ) and low baryon chemical potential, where QGP formation is expected to occur.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: At such a temperature, the Υ(2S , 3S ) excited states are expected to be suppressed in the QGP [6], thus allowing the calibration of its temperature.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Conducting measurements of various quarkonium states (together with open heavy-flavours (HF)) as a function of rapidity and system size would permit to scan the phase-transition region.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Moreover, AFTER@LHC can study the transport properties of the QGP accounting for its longitudinal expansion.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: By measuring particle yields and flow coefficients v N as a function of rapidity, AFTER@LHC can access the temperature dependence of the medium shear viscosity while probing different energy densities.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: A proper interpretation of the AA data probably requires a complete set of v N coefficient measurements in smaller systems (pp, pA) to study the collectivity with new observables, like heavy-flavour hadrons, which will be abundantly produced at AFTER@LHC.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Other items of interest also include the study of the heavy-quark energy-loss mechanisms in the QGP via D meson measurements as a function of the rapidity and p T , and the universality of the initial-state effects from pA to AA collisions with the Drell-Yan probe.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In these proceedings, we will focus on the performance of AFTER@LHC for light and heavy-flavour production.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Possible technical implementations at the LHC and luminosities
In the following, we will discuss the usage of an internal (solid or gaseous) target inside one of the existing LHC experiments (LHCb or ALICE) as a main way to achieve the AFTER@LHC physics goals.
body_text.section: Possible technical implementations at the LHC and luminosities

body_text.text: Such kinds of solutions enable to conduct a fixed-target programme at a limited cost, with a limited civil engineering, and on a shorter timescale.
body_text.section: Possible technical implementations at the LHC and luminosities

body_text.text: The LHCb experiment has demonstrated the feasibility of injecting low-density noble gases inside the vacuum chamber of its Vertex Locator detector using the SMOG system [7].
body_text.section: Possible technical implementations at the LHC and luminosities

body_text.text: This setup has proven that a parasitic operation of a fixedtarget programme with a collider programme is possible, without inducing a decrease of the beam lifetime.

body_text.section: Possible technical implementations at the LHC and luminosities

body_text.text: The ALICE and LHCb detectors are both well suited to conduct a fixed-target programme of AFTER@LHC.
body_text.section: Possible technical implementations at the LHC and luminosities

body_text.text: The LHCb detector is fully instrumented in the forward region, with excellent particle identification (PID) performance.
body_text.section: Possible technical implementations at the LHC and luminosities

body_text.text: It has a mid-to backward coverage in the center-of-mass frame in the fixed-target mode, which reaches large negative Feynman x F .
body_text.section: Possible technical implementations at the LHC and luminosities

body_text.text: The ALICE detector also provides a similar coverage in the mid-to backward region thanks to its current muon arm and future Muon Forward Tracker.
body_text.section: Possible technical implementations at the LHC and luminosities

body_text.text: The long absorber upstream the muon tracking stations is a key feature to reduce the combinatorial background for Drell-Yan studies in pA/AA.
body_text.section: Possible technical implementations at the LHC and luminosities

body_text.text: In addition, the central barrel of ALICE provides a very backward coverage in the fixed-target mode with good PID capabilities, allowing one to reach the end of the phase space for several identified soft probes.

body_text.text: Projected performance for light and heavy-flavours

The measurement of the flow coefficients at mid-and backward rapidity in the c.m.s frame is interesting to test hydrodynamic calculations accounting for the longitudinal expansion of the formed medium.
body_text.section: Projected performance for light and heavy-flavours

body_text.text: Indeed, AFTER@LHC would give us insight on the QGP behaviour at low energy, in a rapidity region seldom probed.

body_text.text: Conclusion
The AFTER@LHC study group is currently investigating the possibilities offered by a future multipurpose fixed-target experiment at the LHC, in the sector of high-x, spin and heavy-ion physics.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: Several possible implementations of a fixed-target setup inside an existing LHC experiment (ALICE or LHCb) are currently explored and the expected integrated yearly luminosities have been derived for each setup.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: In these proceedings, we have presented a selection of projected performance for light and heavy-flavour production at AFTER@LHC.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: It has been shown that the elliptic flow of identified particles can be measured accurately with an ALICE-or LHCb-like detector, after only few hours of Pb-Pb data taking at √ s NN = 72 GeV, opening the path for a study of the temperature dependence of the medium shear viscosity.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: Both in pXe, and PbXe collisions, the Υ(nS ) yields can already be measured after one year of data taking.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: It will allow to calibrate the QGP thermometer in an energy domain between the ones probed at SPS and RHIC using Υ excited states suppression in the QGP.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: Accurate measurements in pXe collisions will complement the PbXe studies, for a proper interpretation of the CNM effects.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: Finally, the large D 0 meson yields expected to be recorded in pp collisions at √ s = 115 GeV at large-x, will be decisive to constrain the proton IC content and to provide valuable inputs for cosmic-ray physics.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: The study of open heavy-flavour hadrons in pA/AA will permit to study collectivity in small systems with new probes and to study heavy-quark energyloss mechanisms in a dense medium.
body_text.section: Conclusion
